projectPurpose: To provide a free and open-source, data-driven, and performant game engine built in Rust, focusing on simplicity and modularity for creating 2D and 3D games across various platforms.
mainFeatures: Data-driven architecture using a custom ECS
Fast: Massively Parallel and Cache-Friendly ECS

alternatives.name: Godot Engine
mainFeatures: Node-based scene system and visual editor
Multiple programming language support (GDScript, C#, C++, GDExtension)

alternatives.name: Unity
mainFeatures: Visual editor and extensive asset store

alternatives.name: Unreal Engine
mainFeatures: Used in film and other industries

marketPositioning: Bevy is positioned as a modern, open-source, data-driven game engine built in Rust, emphasizing simplicity, modularity (via ECS and a plugin ecosystem), and performance. It differentiates itself from more established engines like Unity and Unreal Engine through its Rust foundation, focus on a code-centric and modular workflow, and a performant ECS. While it may be less feature-complete and mature than the major proprietary engines or even Godot which has a full editor, its strengths in performance, memory safety (due to Rust), and a growing ecosystem of plugins appeal to developers seeking more control and a modern, data-oriented approach to game development, particularly within the Rust community. It competes with other Rust engines like Fyrox but offers a different philosophy, favoring code and modularity over a fully integrated visual editor.
